title: Treasury yields rise, curve inverts further after Bullard estimates fed-funds rate needs to go to 5%-7%
text:
* The yield on the 2-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD02Y jumped 8.9 basis points to 4.452% from 4.363% on Wednesday. That's the biggest one-day gain for the 2-year yield since Nov. 3, based on 3 p.m. figures from Dow Jones Market Data.

* The yield on the 10-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD10Y rose 8.1 basis points to 3.774% from 3.693% as of Wednesday afternoon. That's the 10-year yield's biggest one-day advance since Oct. 20.

* The yield on the 30-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD30Y advanced 2.8 basis points to 3.888% from 3.860% as of late Wednesday. That's the largest one-day gain in the 30-year rate since Nov. 9.

What drove markets

Six-month through 30-year Treasury yields moved higher in reaction to a presentation by St. Louis Fed President James Bullard, which suggested that the Fed's main policy rate target may need to get to around 5% to 7%. While Bullard didn't explicitly say in his speech how high the rate needs to go, the policy maker did say the rate would have to be increased further to reach a "sufficiently restrictive level." Read: This is the chart that is rattling U.S. financial markets Thursday

Some traders took Bullard's estimates with a grain of salt, considering his reputation as something of an outlier on the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee. However, hours after Bullard's presentation, his colleague Neel Kashkariof the Minneapolis Fed said that the central bank needs to keep raising rates until it is sure inflation has hit a ceiling. On Thursday, markets were pricing in an 81% probability that the Fed will raise borrowing costs by another 50 basis points, to a range of 4.25% to 4.5% on Dec. 14, and a 19% chance of a 75-basis-point hike next month, according to the CME FedWatch tool. Traders also moved up their expectations for how high the fed-funds rate target might go next year, to further above 5%, but they don't yet see a significant chance of a 6% policy rate.

Read: Goldman Sachs sees new rate hike in 2023, with targeted range for fed funds rising to 5%-5.25%

In U.S. economic releases, initial weekly jobless claims fell slightly to 222,000 in mid-November. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had expected new claims to total 225,000 for the seven days that ended Nov. 12. The Philadelphia Fed'smanufacturing index sank to negative 19.4 in November from negative 8.7 in the prior month, and construction on new houses fell 4.2% in October.

U.K. 10-year gilt yields BX:TMBMKGB-10Y rose 5.4 basis points to 3.201% after the government'sautumn budget statement.

What analysts are saying

"The idea of rate hikes continuing for longer was supported by several Fed speakers, who were sounding more hawkish, commenting that there is still plenty of work to do. James Bullard, known for his hawkish stance, said that even dovish policy assumptions require further rate hikes," said Fiona Cincotta, senior financial markets analyst at City Index in London.

Treasury yields rise, curve inverts further after Bullard estimates fed-funds rate needs to go to 5%-7%
